------=_NextPart_000_01B4_01C9FC8E.AEB62CE0
Content-Type: text/plain;
	charset="us-ascii"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit

All,
 
I tend to agree with Ken Stanley.  My only study on the effect of activation
functions was conducted on a series of 100 double pole balancing experiments
using the sigmoid, steepened sigmoid and step function (as defined in
SharpNEAT).
 
My study showed the step function performed best, but more study should be
done.
 
Ken Lloyd
 
=================
Kenneth A. Lloyd
CEO & Director Systems Science
Watt Systems Technologies Inc.
kalloyd@...
kenneth.lloyd@...
505-918-6988 Cellular direct
www.wattsys.com
 
 

  _____  

From: neat@yahoogroups.com [mailto:neat@yahoogroups.com] On Behalf Of
Kenneth Stanley
Sent: Thursday, July 02, 2009 12:47 PM
To: neat@yahoogroups.com
Subject: [neat] Re: HyperNEAT Activation Functions





Colin, there really has never been a definitive study as far as I know on
how different sets of activation functions affect performance. I am sure it
would be domain-dependent. It is possible that some functions with abrupt
changes could complement their more gradual counterparts, or it could turn
out disruptive for some reason. It's hard to say. But my feeling is that in
general it is not a critical kind of decision, though it might affect
performance to some extent.

ken

--- In neat@yahoogroups. <mailto:neat%40yahoogroups.com> com, Colin Green
<colin.green1@...> wrote:
>
> 2009/7/1 Kenneth Stanley <kstanley@...>:
> >
> > Colin, I don't think there is any agreed standard set. However, I
generally
> > recommend not having more than one of each kind.
> 
> Understood. Start with a minimal set and maybe introduce others at a
> later time if they show promise. E.g. I wonder about functions with
> abrupt changes in rate of change, e.g. abs and square, and whether
> they are complementary or substitutes for functions with a similar
> overall profile but with smoother curves, e.g. gaussian and sine.
> 
> > I also agree that something like an unbounded linear function can have
> > unintended consequences.
> >
> > My guess is that even sigmoids and Gaussians alone can work well,
although
> > it's just a hunch.
> >
> 
> Thanks.
>





------=_NextPart_000_01B4_01C9FC8E.AEB62CE0
